questions.text: Which cells are impacted in multiple sclerosis?
Which functional area is most likely to be impacted by the vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus in this female patient?
questions.explanation:
Brodmann’s numbers

Function

Location

BA 1, 2, 3

 
  • Primary Somatosensory Cortex
  • Processes tactile information from the body.

Postcentral gyrus.

BA 4
  • Primary Motor Cortex
  • Controls voluntary movements via corticospinal and cortico-nuclear tracts.

Precentral gyrus.

BA 8

  • Prefrontal Cortex
  • Involved in planning and decision-making.

The anterior part of the frontal lobe.

 

BA 17

 
  • Primary Visual Cortex (V1)
  • Processes visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus. (Option D ruled out)

Occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus, cuneus, and lingual gyrus).

BA 22
  • Language comprehension (Wernicke’s area) (Option B ruled out)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 41
  • Primary auditory cortex (Option C ruled out)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 42
  • Secondary auditory cortex

Adjacent to BA 41

 

BA 44 and 45
  • Broca’s area
  • Speech production. (Motor speech) (Option A )
  • BA 44 (Opercular part): Syntactic processing (grammar).
  • BA 45 (Triangular part): Semantic processing (meaning).
  • Left BA 44 is typically larger, reflecting language dominance.

Inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe.

questions.text: Which fibre is responsible for High-frequency vibration, pressure sensation?
questions.explanation:
Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Pacinian Corpuscle
(Option A)

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Meissner Corpuscle
(Option C ruled out)

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Nonhairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Merkel’s Disc (Option D ruled out)

Disc-shaped expansion made up of Merkel cells and Aβ-afferent nerve endings
  • Detect continuous touch and pressure,
  • Transmit strong initial signal and weaker sustained signal,
  • Localize touch sensations (Two point discrimination),
  • Determine texture

Underneath the epithelium of the skin

Free Nerve Ending (Option B ruled out)

Unencapsulated nerve endings

Detect touch and pressure

Found everywhere in skin

questions.explanation:
Brodmann Area

Function

1, 2, 3

Primary somatosensory cortex; processes tactile information.

4

Primary motor cortex; controls voluntary movements.

5, 7

Somatosensory association areas; integrate sensory input.

6

Premotor/supplementary motor areas; plan movements.

17

Primary visual cortex; processes visual data.

18, 19

Visual association areas; advanced visual processing.

22

Wernicke's area; facilitates language comprehension.

44, 45

Broca's area; involved in speech production.

questions.text: Choose the correct options from the given statements of the enteric nervous system? 1. Vagus is the only afferent from gut 2. Functions independent of brain and SC 3. Myenteric plexus in the lamina propria 4. Exclusively under the influence of nerves 5. Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS

Component

Function

Location

Myenteric Plexus (Auerbach)

Controls motility and peristalsis

Between muscle layers

Submucosal Plexus (Meissner)

Regulates secretion and blood flow

In submucosa

Autonomy

Functions independently but modulated by CNS

Entire gut wall

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the opposition to passive stretching?
questions.explanation:
Tone

Spasticity

Rigidity

Paratonia

Definition

Refers to the tension or resistance in a muscle at rest.

Increased muscle tone characterized by velocity-dependent resistance to passive movement.

Increased resistance to passive movement independent of velocity.

Impaired ability to modulate muscle tone, leading to variable resistance to passive movement.

Underlying Causes

Can be influenced by factors such as muscle strength, neurological conditions, and psychological factors.

Commonly associated with upper motor neuron lesions, such as stroke, cerebral palsy, or multiple sclerosis.

Often seen in conditions like Parkinson's disease, where there is a dysfunction in the basal ganglia.

Typically observed in individuals with frontal lobe dysfunction or certain neurological conditions.

Characteristics

Can be increased (hypertonic) or decreased (hypotonic) depending on the condition.

Characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in muscle tone, meaning the resistance to passive movement increases with higher speed or sudden stretching.

Characterized by a constant, uniform increase in muscle tone regardless of the speed or force applied during passive movement.

Characterized by variable resistance to passive movement, fluctuating between increased and decreased muscle tone.

Associated Symptoms

Can be accompanied by weakness, stiffness, or abnormal postures.

May include muscle spasms, exaggerated reflexes, clonus (rhythmic contractions), and associated functional impairments.

Often associated with a "cogwheel" or "lead-pipe" rigidity, where movements are jerky or exhibit a ratcheting sensation.

Associated with an inability to relax or resistive behavior during passive movement testing.

Management

Treatment may focus on addressing underlying causes, physical therapy, stretching exercises, and relaxation techniques.

Treatment approaches may include physical therapy, medications (such as muscle relaxants or botulinum toxin injections), and modalities like splinting or orthotics.

Management strategies may involve medications targeting the basal ganglia, deep brain stimulation, and physical therapy.

Management includes promoting relaxation techniques, using clear and simple instructions, and modifying the environment to minimize resistance during passive movement.

questions.text: What is the connecting structure between Broca's area and Wernicke's area?
questions.explanation:
Brain Area

Function

Interconnections

  

Broca's Area

Involved in speech production and language processing

- Connected to Wernicke's area via the arcuate fasciculus

- Interconnects with motor cortex and other regions involved in speech

- Receives input from auditory and visual association areas

  
 
 

Wernicke's Area

Involved in language comprehension and interpretation

- Connected to Broca's area via the arcuate fasciculus

- Interconnects with auditory and visual association areas

- Receives input from the angular gyrus and other language-related areas

  
 
 

Angular Gyrus

Involved in language processing and reading

- Connected to Wernicke's area and visual association areas

- Interconnects with Broca's area and other language-related regions

- Receives input from the visual cortex and other language-related areas

  
 
 

Primary Auditory

Cortex

Processes auditory information

- Connected to Wernicke's area and other language-related regions

- Interconnects with Broca's area and other language-related regions

- Receives input from the auditory system

  
 
 

Visual Association

Cortex

Processes visual information

- Connected to Wernicke's area, angular gyrus, and other language areas

- Interconnects with Broca's area and other language-related regions

- Receives input from the visual system

questions.text: What mediates Inverse stretch reflex?
questions.explanation:
Type of Stretch Reflex

Mediator

Monosynaptic

Muscle spindle and sensory neuron

Polysynaptic

Muscle spindle, sensory neuron, and interneuron

Reciprocal Inhibition

Muscle spindle, sensory neuron, and inhibitory interneuron

Golgi Tendon Reflex

Golgi tendon organ and sensory neuron

questions.text: What specific region of the thalamus is associated with the regulation of motor control?
questions.explanation:
Thalamic Nucleus

Function

Ventral Posterolateral (VPL)

Relays somatosensory information from the body to the primary somatosensory cortex

Ventral Posteromedial (VPM)

Relays somatosensory information from the face to the primary somatosensory cortex

Lateral Geniculate (LGN)

Relays visual information from the optic tracts to the primary visual cortex

Medial Geniculate (MGN)

Relays auditory information from the inferior colliculus to the primary auditory cortex

Ventral Anterior (VA)

Contributes to motor control by receiving input from the basal ganglia

Ventral Lateral (VL)

Contributes to motor control by receiving input from the cerebellum

Anterior (AN)

Involved in memory, emotion, and regulation of the limbic system

Intralaminar Nuclei

Involved in arousal, attention, and modulation of pain perception

questions.text: What is the term used to describe increased pain in response to a minor stimulus?
questions.explanation:
Stimulus

Description

Mechanical stimulus

Physical pressure or trauma to tissues or organs

Thermal stimulus

Heat or cold applied to the body

Chemical stimulus

Exposure to irritants or corrosive substances

Electrical stimulus

Electric shocks or currents

Inflammatory stimulus

Inflammation of tissues or organs

Ischemic stimulus

Lack of blood supply to tissues or organs

Nociceptive stimulus

Activation of specialized pain receptors (nociceptors) by harmful or potentially damaging stimuli

Neuropathic stimulus

Damage or dysfunction of the nervous system, resulting in abnormal pain perception

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after suddenly becoming unconscious while working in the field. On examination, his temperature was 105 degrees fahrenheit and his skin turgor was decreased. Which of the following would not be seen in the patient?
questions.explanation:
System

Key Changes

Thermoregulatory

Hyperthermia (>40°C), cellular necrosis at extreme temperatures

Neurological

Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma (cerebral hypoperfusion, inflammation)

Cardiovascular

Tachycardia, hypotension, distributive shock (vasodilation, vascular leakage)

Metabolic

Acidosis (anaerobic metabolism), electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia)

Renal

AKI (rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, tubular necrosis)

Respiratory

Tachypnea, Kussmaul breathing (severe acidosis)

Hematological

Endothelial damage, microthrombosis, DIC

questions.text: What findings would be observed in a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury due to a road traffic accident, whereby the fracture fragment has penetrated the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of fine motor movement of fingers

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.correct_answer: C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Sensory Modalities

Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscal System
  • Touch: Provides precise localization and fine gradations of intensity.
  • Vibration: Detects rapid changes in stimulus through phasic sensations.
  • Proprioception: Contributes to the sense of body position and movement.
  • Pressure: Allows for the perception of fine degrees of pressure intensity.

Pathway

Sensory receptors → Spinal cord (dorsal roots) → Brain (somatosensory cortex)

Neurons

First-order neurons
  • Originate in mechanoreceptors, and enter spinal cord via dorsal roots
  • Pseudo-unipolar neurons with cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion
  • Split into medial and lateral branches:
    • Medial branch: Travels up dorsal column to brain
    • Lateral branch: Synapses in dorsal horn, forming local reflexes, spinocerebellar tracts
  • Fibers from lower thoracic, sacral, and lumbar regions (T7-T12, L, S) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus gracilis
  • Fibers from cervical and upper thoracic regions (C, T1-T6) ascend to medulla without synapsing, forming the fasciculus cuneatus (Option C)

Second-order neurons
  • Synapse in dorsal medulla (cuneate nucleus for upper body, gracile nucleus for lower body)
  • Cross to opposite brain stem side, travel to thalamus (medial lemniscus)

Third-order neurons
  • Synapse in thalamus (ventrobasal complex)
  • Project to somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus, lateral parietal cortex)

questions.text: The patient exhibits symptoms depicted in the image provided below. Shows the site of the lesion Experiences decreased proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the affected side. Has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
In case a small pain stimulus causes more pain, it is called?
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Hyperalgesia (Option C)

Allodynia (Option D ruled out)

Definition

Severe pain from a stimulus that normally causes pain

Pain from a stimulus that normally wouldn't cause pain,

Sensitivity

Both increases sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers

Cause
  1. Primary hyperalgesia: Excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors.
    Eg : Extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin (results from sensitization of pain receptors due to local tissue products like histamine, prostaglandins)
     
  2. Secondary hyperalgesia: It is the facilitation of sensory transmission .
    Eg: Lesions in the spinal cord or thalamus

The exact cause is unknown. Likely involves error in neuronal conduction.

Eg:Painful sensation from a light touch which is never painful

Association

Both types of pain is seen in neuropathic pain and causalgia (severe burning pain in a specific part of the body) (Option B ruled out)
